source.name: City of Orlando. What Goes Where
source.notes: Extracted from the official City of Orlando What Goes Where page. Supplemented with publicly documented Orlando recycling rules.

materials.name: Plastic bottles and containers
instructions: Empty and clean the container
Replace caps; caps stay on
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: Orlando accepts all rigid plastic bottles and containers
No need to remove labels
commonMistakes: Don't include plastic bags or film
Don't include styrofoam containers
Don't include containers with food residue

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
instructions: Empty and clean
Remove metal lids (recycle them separately)
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: All colors of glass are accepted in Orlando
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass; wrap it and place in trash
Don't include window glass, mirrors, or ceramics
Don't include drinking glasses or Pyrex

materials.name: Aluminum, steel and tin cans
instructions: Empty and clean
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: Both aluminum and steel/tin cans are accepted
Labels can stay on
commonMistakes: Don't include aluminum food pans (not accepted in Orlando)
Don't include cans with food residue

materials.name: Cardboard
instructions: Flatten all boxes
Remove packing materials (styrofoam, bubble wrap)
Place in or beside blue recycling cart
notes: Flattened boxes save space in the cart and truck
commonMistakes: Don't include cardboard soaked with grease
Remove all styrofoam and plastic inserts

materials.name: Paper and newspapers
instructions: Place loose in blue recycling cart
Do NOT bag paper in plastic bags
notes: Includes newspapers, paper bags, junk mail, sheets of paper and drink cartons
Shredded paper should go in a paper bag
commonMistakes: Don't bag recyclables in plastic bags
Don't include paper towels or tissues
Don't include wax-coated paper

materials.name: Plastic bags
instructions: Do NOT place in recycling cart
Many grocery stores (Publix, Walmart) have drop-off bins for plastic bag recycling
Otherwise place in trash cart
Empty recyclables directly into the cart; never bag them
notes: Plastic bags harm recycling machinery; they are the #1 contaminant in Orlando's recycling
Orlando specifically warns: empty the recycling directly into the cart
commonMistakes: Never bag your recyclables in plastic bags
Don't put any plastic film in curbside recycling

materials.name: Polystyrene foam (Styrofoam)
instructions: Place in trash cart
Not accepted in Orlando recycling
notes: Polystyrene foam cups and containers are specifically listed as not accepted in Orlando's recycling program
commonMistakes: Don't put styrofoam in the recycling cart
Packing peanuts can sometimes be returned to shipping stores

materials.name: Aluminum food pans
instructions: Not accepted in Orlando recycling
Place in trash cart
notes: Unlike aluminum cans, aluminum food pans are not accepted in Orlando's recycling program
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with aluminum cans; pans are not accepted

materials.name: Fruit / fruit scraps
instructions: Use your City of Orlando composter if you have one
Otherwise place in trash cart
Do NOT place in recycling cart
notes: Request a free composter from the City of Orlando for fruit and food scraps
Fruit breaks down quickly in composting
commonMistakes: Don't put fruit in the recycling cart

materials.name: Vegetables / vegetable scraps
instructions: Use your City of Orlando composter
Otherwise place in trash cart
Do NOT place in recycling cart
notes: All vegetables are compostable
Request a free composter from Orlando
commonMistakes: Don't put vegetables in recycling cart

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Place in trash cart. Orlando composters are not designed for meat
Wrap in newspaper to contain odor
Put out on collection day to avoid attracting animals
notes: Meat attracts pests and creates odor; not suitable for Orlando's home composting program
commonMistakes: Don't put in Orlando composter
Don't put in recycling cart

materials.name: Dairy products
instructions: Place in trash cart
Pour small amounts of expired milk down the drain
Rinse and recycle the container separately
notes: The dairy goes in trash, but yogurt cups and milk jugs are recyclable after rinsing
commonMistakes: Don't compost dairy in Orlando composters
Don't forget to recycle the container

materials.name: Bread and grains
instructions: Use your Orlando composter for bread and grains
Otherwise place in trash cart
notes: Bread composts well but may attract pests; bury under other compost material
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling cart

materials.name: Eggs / eggshells
instructions: Crush eggshells and add to Orlando composter
They add calcium to compost
notes: Eggshells are excellent for composting
commonMistakes: Crush shells for faster breakdown

materials.name: Coffee grounds / tea bags
instructions: Coffee grounds and paper filters: add to Orlando composter
Paper tea bags: compost (remove staple)
Plastic mesh tea bags: trash
notes: Coffee grounds add nitrogen to compost; great for Orlando gardens
commonMistakes: Check that tea bags are paper, not plastic mesh

materials.name: Cooked food / leftovers
instructions: Use Orlando composter for most cooked food (no meat/dairy)
Cooked food with meat/dairy: trash cart
Scrape food off plates into compost or trash
notes: Orlando composters accept most cooked food except meat and dairy
commonMistakes: Don't put meat-heavy leftovers in the composter

materials.name: Snacks and candy (the food)
instructions: The food itself: composter or trash
The wrapper: trash (see candy wrapper / chip bag entries)
Chewing gum: always trash
notes: Separate food from wrapper; they have different disposal paths
commonMistakes: Don't put wrappers in compost
Gum is always trash

materials.name: Food waste (general)
instructions: Orlando offers a free composting program; request a composter from the city
Alternatively, place in trash cart
Do NOT place in recycling cart
notes: The City of Orlando provides free composters to residents upon request
When in doubt about a specific food, it's almost certainly compostable
commonMistakes: Never put food waste in the recycling cart

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Orlando provides separate yard waste pickup
Place in yard waste containers or paper yard waste bags
Check your pickup schedule on orlando.gov
notes: Orlando has a dedicated yard waste collection program
Yard waste is collected on a separate schedule from trash and recycling
commonMistakes: Don't bag yard waste in plastic bags
Don't mix yard waste with trash or recycling

materials.name: Gas / Gasoline
instructions: Never place in trash or recycling
Take to Orange County Hazardous Waste facility
Can also be taken to community collection events
notes: Gasoline is a flammable hazardous material
Featured item on Orlando's What Goes Where page
commonMistakes: Never pour gasoline down drains or on the ground
Don't put in any curbside cart

materials.name: Television / TV
instructions: Do not place in trash or recycling
Take to an electronics recycling drop-off location
Best Buy accepts TVs up to 32 inches for free recycling
Orange County has e-waste collection events
notes: TVs contain hazardous materials and valuable metals
Featured item on Orlando's What Goes Where page
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside trash or recycling
CRT TVs especially contain lead

materials.name: Sharps / Needles
instructions: Place in an FDA-cleared sharps disposal container
When full, take to an approved collection site
Orlando Fire Stations accept sharps containers
CVS and Walgreens may also accept them
notes: Featured item on Orlando's What Goes Where page
Improper disposal puts sanitation workers at serious risk
commonMistakes: Never place loose sharps in trash or recycling
Don't flush needles down the toilet

materials.name: Paint - latex (full or partially full)
instructions: If liquid: take to Orange County hazardous waste facility
To dry out: remove lid, add kitty litter or sawdust, let dry completely
Dried latex paint cans can go in trash
Many communities hold paint swap events
notes: Featured item on Orlando's What Goes Where page
Liquid paint should never go in regular trash
commonMistakes: Don't pour paint down the drain
Don't put liquid paint in trash or recycling

materials.name: Paint - oil-based
instructions: Always take to Orange County hazardous waste facility
Oil-based paint cannot be dried out and trashed
Never pour down drains
notes: Oil-based paints and stains are more toxic than latex
commonMistakes: Don't try to dry out oil-based paint and put in trash
Don't mix with latex paint

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Do not place in trash or recycling
Take to Orange County Hazardous Waste facility
Many hardware stores (Home Depot, Lowe's) accept batteries
Tape terminals of lithium and 9V batteries before transport
notes: Batteries can cause fires in garbage trucks and recycling facilities
commonMistakes: Don't throw batteries in the trash
Don't put in curbside recycling

materials.name: Electronics / E-waste
instructions: Take to an e-waste recycling center
Best Buy offers free e-waste drop-off
Orange County holds periodic e-waste collection events
Delete personal data before disposal
notes: It is illegal to put e-waste in the trash in Florida
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside trash or recycling
Don't forget to wipe personal data

materials.name: Cooking oil / grease
instructions: Orlando has a cooking oil / grease recycling program
Collect in a sealed container and take to a drop-off location
Contact Kimberlie Schionning at 407.246.2657 for grease program info
Never pour down drains
notes: Orlando has a dedicated grease program; see orlando.gov for details
commonMistakes: Don't pour oil or grease down the drain
Don't put liquid oil in trash

materials.name: Large / bulk items
instructions: Schedule a bulk pickup through orlando.gov or call 407.246.2314
Place at curb on your scheduled pickup day
Do not place more than 2 weeks before pickup
notes: Orlando offers bulk / large item pickup service for residents
commonMistakes: Don't leave large items at the curb without scheduling
Don't block sidewalks or storm drains

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Take to a pharmacy drug take-back program
Orlando police stations often have drug take-back boxes
CVS and Walgreens participate in take-back programs
If no drop-off: mix with coffee grounds, seal in container, and trash
notes: Don't flush medications unless the label specifically says to
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications down the toilet
Don't throw in regular trash without making them unusable

materials.name: Pizza box
instructions: Remove leftover food and liners
If heavily greased: tear off the greasy bottom, trash it, and recycle the clean top
Lightly soiled pizza boxes are generally accepted
notes: Modern recycling can handle some grease; a few spots are OK
commonMistakes: Don't include the wax paper liner
A completely saturated box should go in trash or compost

materials.name: Light bulbs
instructions: CFL and fluorescent bulbs contain mercury; take to hazardous waste
LED bulbs: take to e-waste recycling
Incandescent bulbs: wrap and place in trash
Home Depot and Lowe's accept CFL bulbs
notes: Handle fluorescent bulbs carefully to avoid breakage
commonMistakes: Don't put CFL bulbs in regular trash
Don't break fluorescent tubes

materials.name: Paper towels and napkins
instructions: Add to your City of Orlando composter if you have one
Otherwise place in trash
Never place in recycling
notes: Paper towels cannot be recycled; the fibers are too short and contaminated
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling bin

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate wearable clothing to Goodwill, Salvation Army, or local thrift stores
Textile recycling bins are located throughout Orlando
Unwearable textiles can go in textile recycling bins
notes: Keep textiles out of the landfill; even torn items can be recycled into rags or insulation
commonMistakes: Don't put clothing in curbside recycling
Wet or moldy clothing should be trashed

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Take to a tire retailer or auto shop
Orange County has tire collection at the landfill
Many tire shops accept old tires when you buy new ones
notes: Tire dumping is illegal in Florida
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside trash
Don't dump illegally

materials.name: Motor oil
instructions: Collect in a sealed container
Take to AutoZone, O'Reilly, or other auto parts stores
Or take to Orange County Hazardous Waste facility
notes: Most auto parts stores in Orlando accept used motor oil for free
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains
Don't mix with other fluids

materials.name: Aerosol cans
instructions: Must be completely empty
Remove plastic cap
Place empty can in recycling cart
Non-empty aerosols are hazardous waste
notes: Only completely empty aerosol cans go in recycling
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if still pressurized
Never puncture aerosol cans

materials.name: Milk and juice cartons
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap
Place in recycling cart
notes: Drink cartons are specifically listed as recyclable in Orlando
commonMistakes: Don't flatten; 3D shape helps sorting machines

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Most paper coffee cups have plastic lining and are NOT recyclable
Place in trash cart
Plastic lids may be recyclable; check locally
notes: Bring a reusable cup to reduce waste
commonMistakes: Don't put lined paper cups in recycling

materials.name: Diapers
instructions: Wrap tightly
Place in trash cart
notes: Not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Propane tanks
instructions: Never place in trash or recycling
Take to Orange County Hazardous Waste facility
Large tanks can be exchanged at hardware stores
notes: Pressurized containers are a fire and explosion risk
commonMistakes: Never puncture
Don't put in any curbside cart

materials.name: Wax paper / parchment paper
instructions: Place in trash cart
Not recyclable due to wax/silicone coating
notes: Uncoated parchment may be compostable
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with regular paper

materials.name: Bubble wrap and packing materials
instructions: Place in trash cart
Or drop off plastic film at grocery store collection bins
Packing peanuts can be returned to UPS Store
notes: Plastic film jams recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside recycling

materials.name: Book
instructions: Donate if in good condition. Orlando Public Library, Goodwill, and Little Free Libraries accept books
If damaged, remove hardcover binding (trash it) and recycle paper pages
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: Donating is better than recycling; books can be reused many times
Orlando has many Little Free Library locations for book sharing
commonMistakes: Don't throw usable books in the trash; donate them first
Glossy laminated hardcovers should be removed before recycling pages

materials.name: Magazine
instructions: Place in blue recycling cart
No need to remove staples
Glossy coating is fine
notes: Magazines are accepted in Orlando's curbside recycling program
commonMistakes: Don't remove staples; recycling equipment handles them

materials.name: Envelopes and mail
instructions: Regular paper envelopes: place in blue recycling cart
Window envelopes: recycle as-is
Padded/bubble mailers: trash
notes: Small plastic windows in envelopes are fine in Orlando's recycling
commonMistakes: Padded bubble mailers cannot be recycled

materials.name: Wrapping paper
instructions: Metallic, glittery, or laminated wrapping paper: trash cart
Plain paper wrapping (scrunch test; if it stays scrunched, it's recyclable): blue recycling cart
Tissue paper: trash
notes: Most wrapping paper has foil or glitter and goes in the trash
commonMistakes: Don't assume all wrapping paper is recyclable

materials.name: Receipt
instructions: Place in trash cart; do NOT recycle
Most receipts are thermal paper coated with BPA
notes: Thermal paper contaminates recycling with BPA chemicals
commonMistakes: Don't put thermal receipts in recycling

materials.name: Greeting card
instructions: Plain cards: blue recycling cart
Cards with glitter, foil, or batteries (musical cards): trash cart
notes: Musical cards contain batteries; remove and dispose at Orange County Hazardous Waste
commonMistakes: Don't recycle cards with glitter

materials.name: Candy wrapper
instructions: Place in trash cart
Candy wrappers are mixed metallized plastic film; not recyclable
Shake out crumbs first
notes: Candy wrappers look like foil but are actually multi-layer plastic; not accepted in Orlando's recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling; they look metallic but are not aluminum

materials.name: Chip bag
instructions: Place in trash cart
Chip bags are metallized plastic film; not recyclable curbside in Orlando
notes: The shiny interior is aluminum bonded to plastic; cannot be separated
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling; the metallic interior makes them non-recyclable

materials.name: Fast food wrapper
instructions: Place in trash cart
Food-soiled paper is not recyclable
notes: Fast food wrappers are wax-coated and food-contaminated
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy food wrappers in recycling

materials.name: Plastic clamshell container
instructions: Rinse off food residue
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: Clear #1 PET clamshells are accepted in Orlando recycling
Black plastic clamshells are NOT recyclable
commonMistakes: Black plastic clamshells go in trash

materials.name: Egg carton
instructions: Paper/cardboard egg cartons: blue recycling cart or composter
Styrofoam egg cartons: trash cart
Plastic egg cartons: blue recycling cart
notes: Paper egg cartons are also great for Orlando's composting program
commonMistakes: Don't put styrofoam egg cartons in recycling

materials.name: Cereal box
instructions: Flatten the box
Remove and trash the inner plastic bag
Place flattened box in blue recycling cart
notes: Cereal boxes are accepted in Orlando's curbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't forget to remove the plastic liner bag; that goes in trash

materials.name: Snack pouch / drink pouch
instructions: Place in trash cart
Pouches are multi-layer mixed materials; not recyclable in Orlando
notes: Don't confuse with juice boxes/cartons; cartons are recyclable, pouches are not
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside recycling

materials.name: Coffee pod / K-Cup
instructions: Most coffee pods go in trash cart
Nespresso aluminum pods: mail back via their free program
notes: Mixed materials make these non-recyclable in Orlando's curbside program
commonMistakes: Don't put whole pods in recycling

materials.name: Plastic cups
instructions: Rinse out liquid
Clear #1 PET cups: blue recycling cart
Red Solo cups (#6 polystyrene): trash cart
notes: Clear iced coffee cups from Starbucks/Dunkin are usually recyclable in Orlando
commonMistakes: Red Solo cups are NOT recyclable

materials.name: Toothbrush
instructions: Place in trash cart
Mixed plastic and nylon; not curbside recyclable
notes: Consider bamboo toothbrushes for a more sustainable option
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Toothpaste tube
instructions: Place in trash cart
Multi-layer plastic with residue; not recyclable
notes: Some newer tubes are recyclable #2 HDPE; check the label
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling unless specifically labeled recyclable

materials.name: Deodorant container
instructions: Place in trash cart
Mixed materials make these non-recyclable
notes: The mix of plastic types and internal mechanism prevent recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Makeup / cosmetics
instructions: Most makeup containers go in trash cart
Clean empty #1, #2, or #5 plastic containers can sometimes be recycled
notes: Check if your brand offers a container return program
commonMistakes: Small containers fall through sorting screens

materials.name: Broken ceramics / dishes
instructions: Wrap carefully for safety
Place in trash cart
Not recyclable; ceramics contaminate glass recycling
notes: Donate intact dishes to Goodwill or Salvation Army in Orlando
commonMistakes: Never put ceramics in glass recycling

materials.name: Mirror
instructions: Wrap in cardboard for safety
Label as 'BROKEN GLASS'
Place in trash cart
notes: Metallic coating prevents recycling with regular glass
commonMistakes: Never put mirrors in glass recycling

materials.name: CDs / DVDs
instructions: Place in trash cart
Donate working discs to Goodwill
notes: Polycarbonate plastic; not recyclable curbside
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside recycling

materials.name: Ink / toner cartridges
instructions: Return to Staples or Office Depot in Orlando; they offer free recycling
HP, Canon, and Epson have free mail-back programs
notes: Some stores give rewards credit for returning cartridges
commonMistakes: Don't throw in trash; the ink is chemical waste

materials.name: Pens and markers
instructions: Place in trash cart
Too small and mixed-material for recycling
notes: Crayola offers a ColorCycle program for used markers
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside recycling

materials.name: Smartphone / phone
instructions: Factory reset and delete personal data first
Trade in at Verizon, T-Mobile, or AT&T stores in Orlando for credit
Take to Best Buy for free e-waste recycling
Donate working phones to charities
notes: It's illegal to put phones in the trash in Florida
commonMistakes: Don't throw in trash; phones contain lithium batteries
Don't forget to wipe personal data

materials.name: Laptop / computer
instructions: Wipe the hard drive first
Take to Best Buy or Staples in Orlando for free e-waste recycling
Trade in at Apple or Dell for credit
Donate working computers to schools
notes: It's illegal to put e-waste in the trash in Florida
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash
Don't forget to remove personal data

materials.name: Chargers and cables
instructions: Take to Best Buy in Orlando; they accept cables for free
Bundle cables neatly before dropping off
Do NOT put in curbside recycling
notes: Cables tangle in recycling machinery and cause shutdowns
commonMistakes: Never put cables in curbside recycling

materials.name: Headphones / earbuds
instructions: Take to Best Buy for free e-waste recycling
Wireless earbuds contain lithium batteries; do not put in trash
notes: Wired headphones tangle in recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside recycling or trash

materials.name: Paper bag
instructions: Place in blue recycling cart
Can be reused many times before recycling
notes: Paper bags are specifically listed as recyclable in Orlando
commonMistakes: Don't recycle bags heavily soiled with food or grease

materials.name: Straw
instructions: Place in trash cart
Too small for recycling equipment
notes: Straws fall through recycling sorting screens
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Plastic utensils
instructions: Place in trash cart
Too small and contaminated for recycling
notes: Consider reusable utensils instead
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Bottle caps
instructions: Leave plastic caps ON plastic bottles; recycle together in blue cart
Metal caps: collect in a steel can, crimp shut, recycle
notes: Orlando wants caps left on their bottles
commonMistakes: Don't toss loose caps in recycling; they fall through screens

materials.name: Shoes
instructions: Donate wearable shoes to Goodwill or Salvation Army in Orlando
Nike stores in Orlando accept old athletic shoes
Textile recycling bins are located throughout Orlando
notes: Shoes are one of the most commonly donated items
commonMistakes: Don't put shoes in curbside recycling
Tie pairs together when donating

materials.name: Hangers
instructions: Wire hangers: return to dry cleaners
Plastic hangers: trash cart
Never put any hanger in curbside recycling
notes: Hangers jam recycling machinery due to their shape
commonMistakes: Never put hangers in curbside recycling

materials.name: Granola bar wrapper
instructions: Place in trash cart
Multi-layer flexible plastic; not recyclable
notes: Like candy wrappers and chip bags, these are mixed-material packaging
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Frozen food box
instructions: Place in trash cart
Coated with moisture barrier that prevents recycling
notes: The coating that prevents sogginess also prevents recycling
commonMistakes: Don't assume these recycle like regular cardboard

materials.name: Candle
instructions: Wax and wick: trash cart
Glass jar: clean out wax, then recycle the jar
Metal tins: clean and recycle
notes: Wax is not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put wax in recycling
Don't pour hot wax down the drain

materials.name: Cleaning product bottle
instructions: Empty completely
Rinse briefly
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: Most cleaning bottles are #1 or #2 plastic; accepted in Orlando recycling
commonMistakes: Don't recycle bottles that still have product in them

materials.name: Prescription bottle
instructions: Remove the label (personal health info)
Rinse out residue
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: #5 PP plastic; recyclable in Orlando
commonMistakes: Don't forget to remove the label with your personal information

recycle: Plastic bottles and containers (empty, clean, caps on)
Glass bottles and jars (empty, clean, remove lids)
Aluminum, steel and tin cans (empty, clean)
Paper, newspapers, magazines, books, mail, envelopes
compost: Paper towels, napkins, paper plates (in composter)
trash: Candy wrappers, chip bags, snack pouches

recycle: Plastic bags and film; they jam machinery
Candy wrappers, chip bags, snack pouches

tips: Empty recyclables DIRECTLY into the cart; never use plastic bags
Rinse containers; they don't need to be spotless
When in doubt, put it in the trash; contamination hurts recycling
Request a free composter from the City of Orlando
Leave bottle caps ON their bottles
Books in good condition? Donate to Orlando Public Library
Candy wrappers look metallic but are NOT aluminum; trash them
Check your pickup schedule at orlando.gov

locations.name: City of Orlando Solid Waste Division
